{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'a915e53129e7e7e0f5a4ea84ae6543b6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: B.1. LayerNorm Does Not Affect Our Rank h Assumption
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'a915e53129e7e7e0f5a4ea84ae6543b6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Almost all LLMs that have publicly available architecture details use LayerNorm (Ba et al., 2016) or RMSNorm (Zhang & Sennrich, 2019) just before applying the output projection W (Biderman, 2024). LayerNorm begins with a centering step, which projects its input onto a (h − 1)-dimensional subspace (and RMSNorm does not). In theory, this could break our assumption that the rank of the matrix with columns gθ (pi) (i = 1,...,n) has rank h (Lemma 4.1). In practice, all LLMs we surveyed (Biderman, 2024) enabled the LayerNorm bias, which means the matrices had full rank h (besides GPT-2 Small: see Appendix A).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Ba et al .,', 'url': 'cite.ba2016layer', 'start_index': 81}, {'text': '2016', 'url': 'cite.ba2016layer', 'start_index': 92}, {'text': 'Zhang &', 'url': 'cite.zhang2019root', 'start_index': 110}, {'text': 'Sennrich', 'url': 'cite.zhang2019root', 'start_index': 118}, {'text': '2019', 'url': 'cite.zhang2019root', 'start_index': 128}, {'text': 'Biderman', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 180}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 190}, {'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'theorem.4.1', 'start_index': 446}, {'text': 'Biderman', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 487}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 497}, {'text': 'A', 'url': 'appendix.A', 'start_index': 607}], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': '2c46e13dfe1e94b32b9ea7a45cb7e9d7', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: B.2. Stealing Architectural Details About Normalization Layers
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'a915e53129e7e7e0f5a4ea84ae6543b6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'a915e53129e7e7e0f5a4ea84ae6543b6', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The difference between LayerNorm and RMSNorm (Appendix B.1) could enable attackers to deduce whether models used LayerNorm or RMSNorm. If an attacker recovered an initial logit-vector API query response O (p0), then they could apply Lemma 4.1 to O (p1) − O (p0),...,O (pn) − O (p0).1 From the description of the API at the top of Section 4.1, it follows that O (pi) − O (p0) = W(gθ (pi) − gθ (p0)). This subtraction of g terms occurs immediately after LayerNorm,
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'B . 1', 'url': 'subsection.B.1', 'start_index': 55}, {'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'theorem.4.1', 'start_index': 239}, {'text': '1', 'url': 'Hfootnote.1', 'start_index': 282}, {'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.4.1', 'start_index': 338}], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'ecca06cc4f4c2221d39bd95e1660d721', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: 1Throughout this appendix section, we assume the sum of logit outputs is always 0. We can calculate centered logits from logprobs by
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'ecca06cc4f4c2221d39bd95e1660d721', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: subtracting the mean logits across the vocab dimension.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'parent_id': 'ecca06cc4f4c2221d39bd95e1660d721', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 14, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: so cancels the LayerNorm bias term. Hence, if we apply the Lemma 4.1 attack with this subtraction modification to a model using LayerNorm, then the resultant ‘h’ output will be smaller by 1 (due to Appendix B.1). This would imply the model used LayerNorm rather than RMSNorm, because RMSNorm does not project onto a smaller subspace and so would not have a decrease in ‘h’ value if we were to use this subtraction trick.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'theorem.4.1', 'start_index': 65}, {'text': 'B . 1', 'url': 'subsection.B.1', 'start_index': 206}], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '89d7b8cde44b9849a04951633cc6fab0', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '89d7b8cde44b9849a04951633cc6fab0', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: To confirm that the method from Appendix B.2.1 works, we test whether we can detect whether the GPT-2, Pythia and LLAMA architectures use LayerNorm or RMSNorm from their logit outputs alone. We found that the technique required two adjustments before it worked on models with lower than 32-bit precision (it always worked with 32-bit precision). i) We do not subtract O (p0) from logits queries, but instead subtract the mean logits over all queries, i.e. 1 i=1 O (pi). n Since the average of several points in a common affine subspace still lie on that affine subspace, this doesn’t change the conclusions from Appendix B.2.1. ii) We additionally found it helped to calculate this mean in lower precision, before casting to 64-bit precision to calculate the compact SVD.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'B . 2 . 1', 'url': 'subsubsection.B.2.1', 'start_index': 40}, {'text': 'B . 2 . 1', 'url': 'subsubsection.B.2.1', 'start_index': 618}], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '121c385aa491365544590580de3c6d8c', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '89d7b8cde44b9849a04951633cc6fab0', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The results are in Figure 4. We plot the singular value magnitudes (as in Figure 1) and show that there is a drop in the hth singular value for the architectures using LayerNorm, but not for architecture using RMSNorm:
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4', 'url': 'figure.caption.10', 'start_index': 26}, {'text': '1', 'url': 'figure.caption.2', 'start_index': 81}], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '77d473469e7d49e329e57e5f690acf31', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '77d473469e7d49e329e57e5f690acf31', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '77d473469e7d49e329e57e5f690acf31', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '77d473469e7d49e329e57e5f690acf31', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '77d473469e7d49e329e57e5f690acf31', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '77d473469e7d49e329e57e5f690acf31', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '77d473469e7d49e329e57e5f690acf31', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '77d473469e7d49e329e57e5f690acf31', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Figure 4. Detecting whether models use LayerNorm or RMSNorm by singular value magnitudes.

text: Is this attack practical for real models? We perform the same attack on the logprobs we obtained for ada and babbage.2 We see in Figure 5a-b that indeed the drop in the hth singular values occurs for these two models that use LayerNorm (GPT-3’s architecture was almost entirely inherited from GPT-2):

text: Figure 5. Stress-testing the LayerNorm extraction attack on models behind an API (a-b), and models using both RMSNorm and biases (c).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '5ed62f3fec69613e330d5507f58d1edc', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: As a final stress test, we found that all open language models that use RMSNorm do not use any bias terms (Biderman, 2024). Therefore, we checked that our attack would not give a false positive when applied to a model with RMSNorm but with biases. We chose Gopher-7B (Rae et al., 2022), a model with public architectural details but no public weight access,
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Biderman', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 106}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 116}, {'text': 'Rae et al .,', 'url': 'cite.gopher', 'start_index': 267}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.gopher', 'start_index': 279}], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '5ed62f3fec69613e330d5507f58d1edc', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: 2Unfortunately, we deleted the logprobs for GPT-3.5 models before we created this attack due to security constraints.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'parent_id': '5ed62f3fec69613e330d5507f58d1edc', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 15, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: that uses RMSNorm but also biases (e.g. on the output logits). In Figure 5c we show that indeed the hth singular value does not decrease for this model that uses RMSNorm.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5c', 'url': 'figure.caption.11', 'start_index': 73}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c81069e3d60910ffa567dc05c5ba72ce', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 18}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c81069e3d60910ffa567dc05c5ba72ce', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'subsection.4.2', 'start_index': 33}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '07c69f443ce1e683be0354008fce9af1', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Lemma 4.2 In the logit-API threat model, under the assumptions of Lemma 4.1: (i) The method from Section 4.2 recovers ˜W = W·G for some G ∈ Rh×h; (ii) With the additional assumption that gθ(p) is a transformer with residual connections, it is impossible to extract W exactly.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 6}, {'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'theorem.4.1', 'start_index': 72}, {'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'subsection.4.2', 'start_index': 105}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '07c69f443ce1e683be0354008fce9af1', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: We first give a short proof of (i):
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '07c69f443ce1e683be0354008fce9af1', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: ˜W = W · G, recall Lemma 4.1: we have access to Q⊤ = W · H for some H ∈ Rh×n. Proof. (i) To show we can recover Using the compact SVD of Q from the method in Section 4.2, W · H · V = U · Σ. We know G := H · V ∈ Rh×h, hence if we take ˜W = U · Σ, we have ˜W = W · G.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'theorem.4.1', 'start_index': 25}, {'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'subsection.4.2', 'start_index': 166}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '07c69f443ce1e683be0354008fce9af1', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Proving Lemma 4.2(ii) requires several steps due to the complexity of the transformer architecture: we progressively strengthen the proof to apply to models with no residual connections (C.1), models with residual connections (C.2), models with RMSNorm (C.4), LayerNorm (C.5) and normalization with an ε term (C.6).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 14}, {'text': 'C . 1', 'url': 'subsection.C.1', 'start_index': 187}, {'text': 'C . 2', 'url': 'subsection.C.2', 'start_index': 227}, {'text': 'C . 4', 'url': 'subsection.C.4', 'start_index': 254}, {'text': 'C . 5', 'url': 'subsection.C.5', 'start_index': 271}, {'text': 'C . 6', 'url': 'subsection.C.6', 'start_index': 310}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '07c69f443ce1e683be0354008fce9af1', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: C.1. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With Fully-connected Layers
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 20}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c81069e3d60910ffa567dc05c5ba72ce', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii). As a gentle warmup, we prove (ii) under the additional assumption that the model does not use normalization layers (LayerNorm or RMSNorm) in its architecture. To prove (ii) we show it is possible to find a two distinct sets of model parameters θ,θ′ with different embedding projection matrices that result in identical API outputs.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 15}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c2d1eed421e09e44cd342b80d1c1a226', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: We begin with a simpler case where gθ does not have residual connections but a fully connected (FC) final layer. In this case, for any invertible h × h matrix S, we have that gθ (p) = Sgθ′ (p) where θ′ is the same as θ except that the weights of the final FC layer are pre-multiplied by S−1. Hence, if gθ has a final FC layer, it is impossible to distinguish between the embedding projection layer W acting on gθ and the embedding projection layer W · S acting on gθ′, given access to the output of the API O only.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c2d1eed421e09e44cd342b80d1c1a226', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: C.2. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) With Residual Layers More generally, if gθ is composed of residual layers but no normalization layers then gθ(p) = P i Li(p), where Li(p) is the output of the ith residual layer in the model, ignoring the skip connection (Elhage et al., 2021; Veit et al., 2016). Assume also that each Li has a final layer that is a fully connected linear layer and a linear input layer (this assumption is true for both attention and MLP modules in transformers without normalization layers). Constructing θ′ such that each Li has input weights pre-multiplied by S−1 and output FC weights multiplied by S, we have gθ′(p) = P i SLi(p) = S · gθ(p) by linearity. Finally, by using a new embedding projection matrix (S−1)⊤ ·W⊤ and calculating
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 20}, {'text': 'Elhage et al .,', 'url': 'cite.elhage2021mathematical', 'start_index': 250}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.elhage2021mathematical', 'start_index': 265}, {'text': 'Veit et al .,', 'url': 'cite.resnet_shallow_path', 'start_index': 271}, {'text': '2016', 'url': 'cite.resnet_shallow_path', 'start_index': 284}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c2d1eed421e09e44cd342b80d1c1a226', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: ((S−1)⊤ ·W⊤)⊤ · gθ′(p) = W · gθ(p), we have shown that logit outputs are identical and so again we cannot distinguish these transformers by querying O and O′ alone.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c2d1eed421e09e44cd342b80d1c1a226', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: C.3. Normalization Layers and Orthogonal Matrices
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c81069e3d60910ffa567dc05c5ba72ce', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: In Sections C.3-C.6 we can no longer use general invertible matrices S in our arguments, and must instead use orthogonal matrices, matrices U such that U⊤U = I. In models with LayerNorm, we specialise further, too (Appendix C.5).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C . 3', 'url': 'subsection.C.3', 'start_index': 12}, {'text': 'C . 6', 'url': 'subsection.C.6', 'start_index': 16}, {'text': 'C . 5', 'url': 'subsection.C.5', 'start_index': 224}], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '0fd1ae9e90700b0c05c6f16bdc9142d5', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Lemma C.1. The RMSNorm operation is equal to x 7→ Wn(x) + b where W is a diagonal matrix.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '0fd1ae9e90700b0c05c6f16bdc9142d5', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Proof. RMSNorm is conventionally written as
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '0fd1ae9e90700b0c05c6f16bdc9142d5', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '0fd1ae9e90700b0c05c6f16bdc9142d5', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c81069e3d60910ffa567dc05c5ba72ce', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '4178f2bd7c8cd1fb839a483dcf0f9ac5', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': '4178f2bd7c8cd1fb839a483dcf0f9ac5', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c81069e3d60910ffa567dc05c5ba72ce', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'c81069e3d60910ffa567dc05c5ba72ce', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'parent_id': 'bda2eaf7759ea3b9aa52f20797ca4eaa', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 16, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: where w is multiplied elementwise by normalized x. Clearly this can be written as a diagonal matrix. Further, we can multiply
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3250be4bfdb12d50305101407bb52b02', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: h to cancel that factor in the denominator of Equation (4). Since n(x) = x/||x|| = x
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3250be4bfdb12d50305101407bb52b02', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3250be4bfdb12d50305101407bb52b02', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3250be4bfdb12d50305101407bb52b02', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Intuitively, the proof in Appendix C.2 relied on pre-multiplying the input projection weight of layers by a matrix S−1, so that this cancelled the rotation S applied to the model’s hidden state (called the ‘residual stream’ in mechanistic interpretability literature (Elhage et al., 2021)). Formally, if we let the input projection layer be M, we were using the fact that (cid:0)MS−1(cid:1)(Sx) = Mx. However, since models with normalization layers use these before the linear input projection, the result of applying S to the hidden state, if we apply the same procedure, produces the activation
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C . 2', 'url': 'subsection.C.2', 'start_index': 35}, {'text': 'Elhage et al .,', 'url': 'cite.elhage2021mathematical', 'start_index': 268}, {'text': '2021', 'url': 'cite.elhage2021mathematical', 'start_index': 283}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3250be4bfdb12d50305101407bb52b02', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3205959507915627ebff920ab9b1668b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3205959507915627ebff920ab9b1668b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: but since in general n and S do not commute, we cannot conclude that the S transformations preserve the transformer’s outputs. We will show that if we take S = U an orthogonal matrix, then we still get a general impossibility result.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3205959507915627ebff920ab9b1668b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: To do this, we will need a simple result from linear algebra:
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3205959507915627ebff920ab9b1668b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Lemma C.2. Let x ∈ Rh. Then the normalization map n(x) := x
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3205959507915627ebff920ab9b1668b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Proof of Lemma C.2. We need to show that Ux
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C . 2', 'url': 'theorem.C.2', 'start_index': 15}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': 'f666e398a6af199471e648df01fec165', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': 'f666e398a6af199471e648df01fec165', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: ||Ux||. This is true since x⊤U⊤Ux = xTx, so ||Ux|| = ||x||.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': 'f666e398a6af199471e648df01fec165', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: C.4. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With RMSNorm
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 20}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: In Lemma C.2, we showed that orthogonal matrices U commute with normalization. Hence if we multiply all layer output weights by U, but pre-multiply all layer input projection weights by WU⊤W−1, then the effect of the linear projection layer is
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C . 2', 'url': 'theorem.C.2', 'start_index': 9}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3b74bc169d4ed6b7be6762788ad1e2db', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3b74bc169d4ed6b7be6762788ad1e2db', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3b74bc169d4ed6b7be6762788ad1e2db', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: which is identical to the original model. Applying this procedure to all layers added to the hidden state (using the different W diagonal matrices each time) gives us a model gθ′(p) such that gθ′(p) = Ugθ′(p) so a different embedding projection matrix WU⊤ will give identical outputs to the original model gθ(p) (with embedding projection W).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3b74bc169d4ed6b7be6762788ad1e2db', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Note that we ignore what happens to b in the above arguments, since any sequence of affine maps applied to a constant b ∈ Rh yields a constant b′ ∈ Rh, and we can just use b′ instead of b in gθ′.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '3b74bc169d4ed6b7be6762788ad1e2db', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: C.5. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With LayerNorm
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 20}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The LayerNorm operation is the composition of a centering operation x 7→ x − ¯x with RMSNorm (i.e. first centering is applied, then RMSNorm). Therefore the identical argument to Appendix C.4 goes through, besides the fact that we need U to also commute with the centering operation. Since the centering operation fixes a (h − 1) dimensional subspace defined by 1Tx = 0 where 1 ∈ Rh is the vector of ones, it is enough to impose an additional condition that U1 ∈ {−1,1}.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C . 4', 'url': 'subsection.C.4', 'start_index': 186}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0eede7ce5f992d54b4ac0b73bda527ce', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: C.6. Proof of Lemma 4.2(ii) in Models With Normalization ε ̸= 0
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 20}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': '0d48ba34283a6d87f08773db0c1a6b72', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: We now extend to realistic models where the ε in the denominator of LayerNorm is not 0. We can do this because the only fact we used about x 7→ n(x) was that x 7→ n(Ux) was identical to x 7→ Un(x). In turn Lemma C.2 relied on
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': 'cee2cf9f4545d4da4e06fbcfda204325', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': 'cee2cf9f4545d4da4e06fbcfda204325', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: ||Ux|| = ||x|| due to orthogonality. But adjusting n(x) to n′(x) := x
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': 'cee2cf9f4545d4da4e06fbcfda204325', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: h||x||2 + ε (i.e. normalization with an epsilon), since ||x|| = ||Ux||, n′ commutes with U, and so the proofs in Appendix C.4 and Appendix C.5 still work when using n′ instead of n.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C . 4', 'url': 'subsection.C.4', 'start_index': 122}, {'text': 'C . 5', 'url': 'subsection.C.5', 'start_index': 139}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': 'cee2cf9f4545d4da4e06fbcfda204325', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Therefore finally, we have proven the impossibility result Lemma 4.2(ii) in all common model architectures (all non-residual networks that end with dense layers, and all transformers from Biderman (2024)).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 2', 'url': 'theorem.4.2', 'start_index': 64}, {'text': 'Biderman', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 187}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.stellabidermangooglesheet', 'start_index': 197}], 'page_number': 17, 'parent_id': 'cee2cf9f4545d4da4e06fbcfda204325', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 17, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: D. Derivation of Binarized Logprob Extraction (Section 5.4)
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5 . 4', 'url': 'subsection.5.4', 'start_index': 55}], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: To begin, observe that we can write
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '28df67a427fd57ed99f9e1cdf8eb332d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: i exp(logiti) and p = exp(logitt) /N. Then, we can rewrite

text: ytop = logittop − logN ytop = logittop − log(N + (1/e − 1)pN)

text: Related work. Concurrent work (Morris et al., 2023) discusses a similar but weaker two-query logprob extraction. Their attack requires a logit bias larger than logittop − logiti and top-2 logprob access; our attack works as soon the logit bias is allowed to be nonzero, and with top-1 logprob access.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Morris et al .,', 'url': 'cite.morris2023language', 'start_index': 31}, {'text': '2023', 'url': 'cite.morris2023language', 'start_index': 46}], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '8b01372a7709a6cbfc9426e03dff2754', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: E. Efficient Recovery of Logits From Top k Logprobs APIs
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: In Section 5.3 of the main body, we presented a simple and practical method for extracting the entire logits vector via multiple queries to an API that only provides the top few logprobs and accepts a logit bias with each query. In this section we present more efficient methods.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5 . 3', 'url': 'subsection.5.3', 'start_index': 11}], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '766344fb850f385d86b04fae4c92698a', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The method we presented earlier uses a reference token. We set this to some arbitrary value (e.g., 0) and then compare the logits for all other tokens to this one. This approach is numerically stable, but is slightly wasteful: of the top K logprobs returned by the API, one is always the reference token. Hence, we only recover K − 1 logits per query with this method.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '766344fb850f385d86b04fae4c92698a', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: In this appendix, we present linear algebraic methods that are able to recover K logits per query to the top-K logprobs API. Setting: Recall that there is an unknown vector z = W · gθ(p) ∈ Rℓ (i.e., the logits for a given prompt p) that we want to recover. We can make multiple queries to the API with the same prompt O(p,b). Each query is specified by a vector b ∈ Rℓ (a.k.a. the logit bias). We receive answers of the form (i,ai(z,b)) ∈ N × R, where i is a token index and ai(z,b) is a logprob:
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '766344fb850f385d86b04fae4c92698a', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '27b1772b13dd2a15b11cea955349f1db', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '7911be09f55b9c0680abfc062f19161b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '7911be09f55b9c0680abfc062f19161b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '8e34abf71d4fc79165cef0ffba2da96d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '8e34abf71d4fc79165cef0ffba2da96d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Each query may receive multiple answers (namely, the K largest ai(z,b) values). For notational simplicity, we denote multiple answers to one query the same way as multiple queries each returning one answer. Suppose queries b1,··· ,bm were asked and we received m answers (i1,ai1(z,b1)) ← O(p,b1),··· ,(im,aim(z,bm)) ← O(p,bm). Our goal is to compute z from the answers ai(z,b).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '8e34abf71d4fc79165cef0ffba2da96d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': '41f7e58928c218e064ed37adf81db318', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: As a starting point, suppose the API only returns the single largest logprob (i.e., K = 1). The approach from Section 5.3 cannot work in this setting because we cannot obtain the logprob of both the reference token and another token at the same time, meaning we can recover less than 1 logit per query.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5 . 3', 'url': 'subsection.5.3', 'start_index': 118}], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': 'dc37edad55e58917cedf95e3c3a36da9', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The high-level idea to overcome this problem is that, instead of normalizing logits relative to a reference token, we shall normalize the logits to be logprobs. That is, we recover the logits with the normalization P j exp(zj) = 1. With this normalization it is no longer necessary to include a reference token in every query.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'parent_id': 'dc37edad55e58917cedf95e3c3a36da9', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 18, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 19, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: E.2. Recovering K Logits From K Logprobs
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 19, 'parent_id': '9400e76e5fefe15f71201cc6ff4a467d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The approach from the previous subsection extends to the setting where each API query returns the top K logprobs. In practice we work with K = 5. We are able to recover K logits. Again, instead of using a reference token to normalize the logits, we will normalize P j exp(zj) = 1. However, in this setting we will need to solve a K-by-K system of linear equations.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 19, 'parent_id': 'ae9f3055bc7716b6315fa4e2dfc1f7e0', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Fix K token indices i1,··· ,iK and let bik = B for k ∈ {1,··· ,K} and bj = 0 for all j /∈ {i1,··· ,iK}. We query the API with this logit bias and assume that B is large enough that the logprobs for i1,··· ,iK are returned as the top K logprobs:
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 19, 'parent_id': 'ae9f3055bc7716b6315fa4e2dfc1f7e0', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 19, 'parent_id': 'ae9f3055bc7716b6315fa4e2dfc1f7e0', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Let z ∈ Rℓ be the (unknown) logits and let N = P
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 19, 'parent_id': 'ae9f3055bc7716b6315fa4e2dfc1f7e0', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: i exp(zi) be the normalizing constant. For each k ∈ {1,··· ,K}, we

text: where A is a K × K matrix with entries
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': 'ac6509f65cbcf0f628e63a0677aacf37', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: if j = k if j ̸= k.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': 'f91f192091089b1af4788456bcee4070', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Note that A is a rank-one perturbation of a diagonal matrix, that is, if 1 is the all-ones vector, then
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': '2941edadd3eab13310f9e9dac08e14fe', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': '2941edadd3eab13310f9e9dac08e14fe', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: where diag1≤k≤K(exp(B − aik(z,b))) denotes a diagonal matrix with the k-th diagonal entry being exp(B − aik(z,b)). Inverting a diagonal matrix is easy and thus we can use the Sherman-Morrison formula to compute the inverse of A:
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': '2941edadd3eab13310f9e9dac08e14fe', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': '2941edadd3eab13310f9e9dac08e14fe', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': '2941edadd3eab13310f9e9dac08e14fe', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': 'f91f192091089b1af4788456bcee4070', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'parent_id': '637f1c428815856a1a1730d16c4a8dd9', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 20, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 21, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: where v ∈ RK is the vector with entries vk = exp(aik(z,b) − B). Hence

text: Note that setting K = 1 yields the same result as in Equation 8.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '8', 'url': 'equation.E.8', 'start_index': 62}], 'page_number': 21, 'parent_id': '484ca540d73738295e644af5c4133149', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Recovery using Equation 9 is more efficient than the method in Section 5.3, as we recover K logits zi1,zi2,··· ,ziK rather than just K − 1 logits. However, if B is large, numerical stability may be an issue. (And, if B is small, the logit bias may be insufficient to force the API to output the desired tokens by placing them in the top K.) Specifically, as B → ∞, we have (1 − e−B)PK j exp(aij(z,b)) → 1 and so the logarithm in Equation 9 tends to log(1 − 1) = −∞; this means we may have catastrophic cancellation.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '9', 'url': 'equation.E.9', 'start_index': 24}, {'text': '5 . 3', 'url': 'subsection.5.3', 'start_index': 70}, {'text': '9', 'url': 'equation.E.9', 'start_index': 435}], 'page_number': 21, 'parent_id': '484ca540d73738295e644af5c4133149', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Related work. Two works published during the responsible disclosure period use a similar procedure, and deal with numerical issues in different ways. (Chiu, 2024) start with a low B for the whole vocabulary, then increase B and ask for all tokens that haven’t appeared before, and repeat until all tokens are covered. (Hayase et al., 2024) use the method in Appendix E.1, and set B = −ˆzi, where ˆzi is an estimate of zi inherent to their application. It is possible variants of this method have been discussed before our or these works, but we are not aware of further references.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'Chiu', 'url': 'cite.openlogprobs', 'start_index': 151}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.openlogprobs', 'start_index': 157}, {'text': 'Hayase et al .,', 'url': 'cite.hayase2024query', 'start_index': 319}, {'text': '2024', 'url': 'cite.hayase2024query', 'start_index': 334}, {'text': 'E . 1', 'url': 'subsection.E.1', 'start_index': 367}], 'page_number': 21, 'parent_id': '484ca540d73738295e644af5c4133149', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 21, 'parent_id': 'd120c44824c564a20d3cbfb58a1187bb', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: In general, we may not have have full control over which logprobs the API returns or which logit bias is provided to the API. Thus we generalize the linear algebraic approach above to reconstruct the logits from arbitrary logit biases and tokens.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 21, 'parent_id': 'd9fbd15b86d2ef193e62af5e9a1327ef', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Here I[j = ik] is 1 if j = ik and 0 otherwise. If A is invertible, then this linear system can be solved to recover the logits z. Unfortunately, A is not invertible: Indeed, we know that the solution cannot be unique because shifting all the logits by the same amount yields the exact same answers ai(z,b) = ai(z + 1,b). That is, we expect a one-dimensional space of valid solutions to A · exp(z) = 0. To deal with this we simply add the constraint that z1 = 0 or, equivalently, exp(z1) = 1. This corresponds to the system

text: Here A1:m,2:d denotes A with the first column removed. Note that we are setting m = ℓ − 1. This is the minimum number of query-answer pairs that we need. If we have more (i.e., m ≥ ℓ), then the system is overdetermined. Having the system be overdetermined is a good thing; the extra answers can help us recover the logprobs with greater accuracy. The least squares solution to the overdetermined system is given by 

text: This provides a general method for recovering the (normalized) logits from the logprobs API.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 22, 'parent_id': '728afd3ad5e3893ad860629e195d4608', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: F. How Far Are Our Logprob-Free Attacks From Optimal?
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 22, 'parent_id': 'b5d5c4940e07ec6e18b137c31226161b', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: In the logprob-free API, we have produced attacks capable of recovering logits and ultimately the embedding hidden dimension and embedding matrix up to a similarity transform. We now provide lower bounds on the minimum number of queries required by any attacker attempting model stealing under the logprob-free API threat model.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 22, 'parent_id': '6913fe8692ecbe509a9abc737a3e60b1', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 22, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 22, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 22, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Lemma F.1. Assume the entries of logit ∈ Rl are i.i.d. uniform over [−B,0]. To recover the vector logit up to ∞-norm error ε, the number of queries to O(p,·) we need is at least:
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': 'd2f91c2b66202daebe7422ceaf9ad879', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': 'd2f91c2b66202daebe7422ceaf9ad879', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '96d48077d28af920ef093af6f17f61c3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Proof. The information content of a single logit value in [−B,0] up to ∞-norm error ε is log2(B/ε), assuming a uniform prior over ε-spaced points in the interval. Since the logits are independent, the information encoded in l logit values up to ∞-norm error ε is l log2(100/ε). Any single query to O, no matter how well-crafted, yields at most log2(l) bits, because the output is one of l distinct values. The minimum number of queries required is at least the total information content divided by the information per query, yielding the lower bound l log2(B/ε)/log2(l).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '96d48077d28af920ef093af6f17f61c3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The restriction of biasing at most N tokens at a time gives us a lower bound of
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '96d48077d28af920ef093af6f17f61c3', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': 'd2f91c2b66202daebe7422ceaf9ad879', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: queries, which is a factor of log2(l)/log2(N) worse. For N = 300 and l ≈ 100,000, this is only a factor of 2. For B = 100 and N = 300, we thus need at least
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '93257d43e407d0f60e5800da4f9aea89', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': 'd2f91c2b66202daebe7422ceaf9ad879', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '91cffface5430218b956e2d4cf84243c', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: queries per logit. If we want between 6 and 23 digits of precision, the lower bound corresponds to 1.53 to 3.57 queries per logit. We see that the best logprob-free attack in Table 3 is only about 1 query per logit worse than the lower bound.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '3', 'url': 'table.caption.5', 'start_index': 181}], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '91cffface5430218b956e2d4cf84243c', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The main unrealistic assumption in Lemma F.1 is that the prior over the logit values is i.i.d. uniform over an interval. A better assumption might be that most of the logit values come from a light-tailed unimodal distribution. We leave more realistic lower bounds and attacks that make use of this better prior to future work.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'F . 1', 'url': 'theorem.F.1', 'start_index': 41}], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '91cffface5430218b956e2d4cf84243c', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: G. Recovering W up to an orthogonal matrix
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': 'd2f91c2b66202daebe7422ceaf9ad879', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: In this section, we outline an algorithm for extracting W up to an orthogonal h × h matrix, instead of merely up to a nonsingular h × h matrix as in Appendix C. We do not carry out this attack in practice for models considered in this paper, and leave improving this algorithm as an open problem for future work.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'C', 'url': 'appendix.C', 'start_index': 158}], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: We make a few simplifying assumptions:
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: 1. We merge the final LayerNorm weights γ into W by linearity.3
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: 2. We assume the numerical precision is high enough that after the final LayerNorm, the hidden states are on a sphere.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: 3. There is no degenerate lower-dimensional subspace containing all gθ(p) for all our queries p.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: 4. We assume the ε in RMSNorm/LayerNorm is 0. This is not a critical assumption.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Again, we use the compact SVD on the query output matrix Q = U · Σ · V⊤. Here Q ∈ Rl×n, U ∈ Rl×h, Σ ∈ Rh×h, and V⊤ ∈ Rh×n. Note that the points gθ(p) lie on a sphere in Rh, and U⊤ ·W ∈ Rh×h, hence U⊤ ·W · gθ(p) lie on an ellipsoid in Rh. From now on, it is convenient to work with the points xi = U⊤ ·W · gθ(pi); note that we can compute these points directly, because we know both U and W · gθ(pi). As ellipsoids are equivalently defined by x⊤Ax = 1 for some positive semidefinite (symmetric) matrix A ∈ Rh×h, this implies the following statement: Lemma G.1. There exists a positive semidefinite A ∈ Rh×h such that x⊤
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: 3For a full explanation of this method of rewriting the unembedding matrix, see Appendix A.1, ‘Folding LayerNorm’ in Gurnee et al.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'parent_id': '74ed20aa090f6dfcdb3418f3acc0f619', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 23, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Stealing Part of a Production Language Model
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 24, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Because A is positive semidefinite, we can write A = M⊤ ·M for some M. Here is the key observation: Lemma G.2. W = U ·M−1 · O for some orthogonal matrix O.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'b782d32c056b3c2788c837af78747aca', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Proof. We know that gθ(pi) lie on a sphere. The equation x⊤ i M⊤Mxi = 1, which is equivalent to ∥Mxi∥ = 1. This means that Mxi lie on a sphere. Because Mxi = M · U⊤ ·W · gθ(pi), we have that M·U⊤ ·W is a norm-preserving transformation on the points gθ(pi). By the assumption that gθ(pi) are not in a degenerate lower-dimensional subspace, we have that M · U⊤ · W =: O is a norm-preserving endomorphism of Rh, hence an orthogonal matrix. This directly implies W = U ·M−1 · O as claimed.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'b782d32c056b3c2788c837af78747aca', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: i Axi = 1 is equivalent to x⊤
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'b782d32c056b3c2788c837af78747aca', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: This means that, to extract W up to an orthogonal matrix, it’s enough to recover some M satisfying ∥Mxi∥ = 1 for all i. To compute M, we can actually recover the positive semi-definite A satisfying Lemma G.1, which would give us a feasible M by SVD or Cholesky decomposition.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'G . 1', 'url': 'theorem.G.1', 'start_index': 203}], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'b782d32c056b3c2788c837af78747aca', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The final observation is that the system in Lemma G.1 (x⊤ i Axi = 1 for all i) is linear in the h(h + 1)/2 distinct entries of A. By generating more than h(h + 1)/2 values for xi (and again assuming no degeneracy), we can therefore solve a large system of linear equations, and in principle recover A, and hence M, and hence W. Note that any solution A will be positive semidefinite because an overdetermined linear system has at most one solution. However, we do not know how to solve these systems of linear equations in h2 variables efficiently (h > 750 in all our experiments); so in practice we resort to reconstructing weights up to an arbitrary h × h matrix, as described in Appendix C.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': 'G . 1', 'url': 'theorem.G.1', 'start_index': 49}, {'text': 'C', 'url': 'appendix.C', 'start_index': 688}], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'b782d32c056b3c2788c837af78747aca', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'b782d32c056b3c2788c837af78747aca', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'b782d32c056b3c2788c837af78747aca', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: Quantization is a popular strategy for decreasing a model’s memory footprint and speeding up inference. In addition to these benefits, using lower-precision number representations also effectively adds noise. As noted in Section 8.2, adding noise to the output logits could prevent our attack. A natural question that follows is, does quantization add sufficient noise to make our attack ineffective or more difficult to carry out?
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '8 . 2', 'url': 'subsection.8.2', 'start_index': 228}], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'd826914e087a5d221183273e55065a64', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: For a simple test, we quantize Llama-7B at both 8-bits and 4-bits, and compare our baseline attack (Section 4.1) to the default 16-bit implementation. We quantize using bitsandbytes (Dettmers et al., 2022), which HuggingFace supports for out-of-the-box quantization of model weights and lower-precision inference (Figure 6). We observe no meaningful differences at different levels of quantization; querying each model results in recovering the same same embedding matrix dimension h in the same number of queries. Given that 8-bit and 4-bit quantization are generally observed to not have a large impact on performance, this is perhaps an unsurprising result; any noise from quanitization does not seem to have a meaningful impact on the logits (in the context of our attack).
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '4 . 1', 'url': 'subsection.4.1', 'start_index': 108}, {'text': 'Dettmers et al .,', 'url': 'cite.dettmers2022optimizers', 'start_index': 183}, {'text': '2022', 'url': 'cite.dettmers2022optimizers', 'start_index': 200}, {'text': '6', 'url': 'figure.caption.12', 'start_index': 321}], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'd826914e087a5d221183273e55065a64', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'b782d32c056b3c2788c837af78747aca', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: One natural defense to our attacks is to obfuscate the logits by adding noise. This will naturally induce a tradeoff between utility and vulnerability—more noise will result in less useful outputs, but increase extraction difficulty. We empirically measure this tradeoff in Figure 5(c). We consider noise added directly to the logits, that is consistent between different queries of the same prompt. To simulate this, we directly add noise to our recovered logits, and recompute the extracted embedding matrix. For GPT-2, we measure the RMSE between the true embedding matrix and the embedding matrix extracted with a specific noise level; for ada and babbage, we measure the RMSE between the noisy extracted weights and the weights we extracted in the absence of noise. We normalize all embedding matrices (to have ℓ2 norm 1) before measuring RMSE.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'links': [{'text': '5 ( c ).', 'url': 'figure.caption.12', 'start_index': 280}], 'page_number': 24, 'parent_id': 'd332e6f334d5712483eb881bedd97294', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}
{'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 24, 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: (b). Differences between consecutive sorted singular values.
metadata: {'languages': ['heb', 'eng'], 'page_number': 25, 'parent_id': 'a3fb5b5677be0f08fc8945a77a370d1d', 'filename': '2403.06634.pdf', 'filetype': 'application/pdf'}

text: The Bonded Manifolds family of products contains products that are alternative for Manifold-Monoblocks. They are 2,3 and 4 gang UV bonded manifold, LB and closed stopcocks.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}

text: This Risk management plan covers all risk management activities required for bonded manifolds development projects as well as their design change projects.

text: First Risk review meeting shall be performed after Design Input and before Design V&V. Risk Management activities are categorized as Design Review Activities along the project
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: The purpose of this document is planning the risk management process for the Bonded Manifold family of products.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Definitions:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: FMEA: Failure Mode and Effect Analysis.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: Harm: physical injury or damage to the health of people, or damage to property or the environment.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: Hazardous situation: circumstances in which people, property, or the environment are exposed to one or more hazard(s).
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: Risk: combination of the probability of occurrence of harm and the severity of that harm.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: RPN: Risk Priority number, Multiply of Severity*Probability*Detectability.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: ALARP:  As Low As Reasonably Possible.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng', 'por'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Method:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['4.1.', 'Risk Management Process description:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['fra', 'eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: Risk Management process will be performed as required by ISO 14971:2007 and BS EN ISO 14971:2012, ("Medical Devices – Application of risk management to medical devices") and in accordance with Elcam's SOP# 03-01-21.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: The process will include Risk Analysis, Risk Evaluation and Risk Control and at the end of the process also Production & Post Production information.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Risk Analysis', 'Risk Evaluation', 'Risk Control', 'Production & Post Production information.'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: (The method for risk analysis and evaluation to be used is mainly FMEA (Fail Mode & Effect Analysis). Other techniques will be used as well when needed.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['FMEA'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: The emphasis will be on risks primarily to the patient, but also to the operator, other persons, other equipment and the environment occurs during the product shelf life and/or in-use life. Risks which effect Elcam's image or Elcam's manufacturing facilities that do not affect product's safety or performance are not included within this Risk Management Process.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['4.1.1.', 'Risk Analysis', 'Risk Analysis', ':'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'i', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: First step is listing the intended use or purpose of the product and its characteristics related to its safety.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: Then, identifying the known or foreseeable hazards and hazardous situations in normal and fault conditions, their causes and estimating the risks for each hazardous situation. This identification will initially be performed by a review meeting after design Input phase, after establishing the Device Requirements and the Product Specifications.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': [', identifying the known or foreseeable hazards and hazardous situations', 'causes', 'risks'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['4.1.2.', 'Risk Evaluation:', 'Risk Evaluation:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: The identified hazardous situations are evaluated for their risk probability of occurrence (P), severity (S) and detectability (D) according to the scales described below. Afterwards the RPN number is calculated by multiplying the ratings for each hazard and the acceptability is determined according to the acceptance criteria.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['probability', '(P)', 'severity (S)', 'detectability (D)', 'RPN', 'acceptance criteria'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b', 'b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: Each parameter (P, S, or D) will be analyzed in order to rank and estimate the risk:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['P', 'S', 'D'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Probability of occurrence', 'Probability of occurrence', '(', 'P', 'P'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'i', 'i', 'b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: Value Probability for occurrence Verbal description for probability 1 Less than 1 in 1,000,000 Evidence that will not occur 2 1:10,000 - 1:1,000,000 Low probability, rare occurrence 4 1:1,000 - 1:10,000 Will occur several times 6 1:100 - 1:1,000 Will occur several times, often 8 More than 1:100 High probability, likely to occur frequently

metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Degree of Severity', 'Degree of Severity', '(', 'S', 'S'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'i', 'i', 'b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: S Rating Severity Severity to Patient/User Severity to Elcam Severity to Manufacture 1 Minor All is fine up to small discomfort, minor damage in performance. All is fine up to deviations in spec border. Small effect on equipment or product, a few production hours loss. 2 Medium Degradation in performance without harm. Damage to image, do not meet spec. Degradation in equipment or its operation small effect on product in non-functional characters, a few days loss. 4 Severe The part does not function but does not cause harm. Need to replace parts, severe impact to image, will not meet fundamental characteristic in spec. Medium degradation in equipment or its operation affecting product in non-functional characters, two-three weeks loss. 6 Severe - critical The product does not function and causes injury or condition requiring medical treatment. Severe impact to image, product will not meet the requirements of spec, market loss. High deterioration in equipment or its operation severely affecting production or product functionality, several week losses. 8 Critical Severe harm to patient: death, irreversible injury or condition or long term medical aid. Low suit, market loss. Severe damage to equipment, not being able to produce at all or producing non-functional products, loss of more than month and a half.

text: Rate according to severity to patient/user or their environment. If the risk has an effect on several fields (patient/user and/or Elcam and/or Manufacture) rate according to the worst of all.
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Rate according to severity to patient/user or their environment. If the risk has an effect on several fields (patient/user and/or Elcam and/or Manufacture) rate according to the worst of all.'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: Degree of Detectability (D) – Relevant mainly to Process risks:
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['Degree of Detectability (D) – Relevant mainly to Process risks:', 'Degree of Detectability (D) – Relevant mainly to Process risks:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: D Rating Defect Detection 1 Defect, if occurred, will always be detected at Elcam during production. 2 Defect, if occurred, will occasionally be detected at Elcam during production. 3 Defects, if occurred, will rarely be detected at Elcam or Will be detected by customer (not end user). 4 Defects, if occurred, will not be detected at Elcam. It will always be detected by the end user.
metadata:
{'emphasized_text_contents': ['D Rating', 'Defect Detection'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'text_as_html': '
D RatingDefect Detection
1Defect, if occurred, will always be detected at Elcam during production.
2Defect, if occurred, will occasionally be detected at Elcam during production.
3Defects, if occurred, will rarely be detected at Elcam or Will be detected by customer (not end user).
4Defects, if occurred, will not be detected at Elcam. It will always be detected by the end user.
', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

metadata: {'category_depth': 2, 'emphasized_text_contents': ['RPN calculation:'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['i'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': '2021d894eaaee156a8dd330deeb6b6c0'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: The calculation of the Risk Priority Number (RPN) is done by multiplying the risk values:         (S x P) or (S x P x D).
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'emphasized_text_contents': [':', '(S x P)', '(S x P x D)'], 'emphasized_text_tags': ['b', 'b', 'b'], 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': 'fa36c144a3952ba69d3aab6a306f544b'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

text: According to the calculated RPN value the priority for mitigation is determined (Risk Priority Level).
metadata: {'category_depth': 0, 'filename': 'Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc', 'languages': ['eng'], 'filetype': 'application/msword', 'parent_id': 'fa36c144a3952ba69d3aab6a306f544b'}
filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc

filename: Risk Management Plan - Bonded Manifolds.doc
